content.description:
A fun TR route of moderate difficulty.  Start in the crack directly below the arete. Climb onto the boulder then step left onto the arete (crux 1).  Follow the arete up and finish on face on the left side (crux 2). 

  You can also start on the face left of the arete which is a bit harder.
content.protection: Not much.  Suitable trees for TR anchors but long (150 ft.) static required.
content.location: The large, blocky arete on the right-facing corner about 25 ft left of Block of Ages.  Look for the dead hemlock on a ledge about 10 feet up.  Also, look for it when being lowered off (ouch!).

content.description: This was the first route I did in CT and I returned to it several times.  The dihedral is steep and pumpy and the pro is decent but strenuous to place.  Stout for its grade.  Stem and jam up the steep dihedral which gets easier above as the angle eases.
content.protection: Standard rack of small wires through med cams.
content.location: White Fandango is one of the left-most routes on the crag.  It is the obvious steep dihedral just left of the nasty looking Phantasmagoria roof.

content.description: Climb the arete that is facing the road. Start on slopey right hand and a jug for the left hand. Keep bumping your right hand up the arete while finding the best holds you can for your left hand. Feet get smaller as you reach the top. This problem is a little tall (making it heady for a V0) and has an awkward/sketchy down climb on the other side of the boulder where you cannot see your feet.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads and a spotter
content.location: The obvious arete on the boulder just to the right of Golden Book.

content.description: Climb the face through three overlaps between Friday the 13th and Fool's Mate.
content.protection: Originally lead with hooks

content.description: Golden Book runs up the crack and to its left. Sunny Side Up is the right hand wall. The start is just before you go under the tunnel formed by the wall and the boulder. Using both small holds on the face and the boulder on your right ascend the steep, almost vertical wall off the desk. After the balancy opening moves, you will clear the boulder and have two options. If you ascend climber's right, the route moves from a 5.7 to a fun 5.5 stretch of climbing thanks to large rectangular blocks of rock. For more of a challenge (5.9 - 5.10) stay to the left and ascend the face to the wall.
content.protection: Use the same anchors you would for Golden Book
content.location: To the immediate right of Golden Book.  Start right at the entrance to the tunnel, making use of the archway behind you as well as the wall to the front of you.

climbs.name: Saturday Night Special
climbs.fa: FA: Chris Stone, Dusty Nelson, ken nichols, 11/1975

content.description: Good warm-up for neighboring Dead Dogs. Crux is 1/2 way up moving through a slight bulge using finger locks and sparse feet. Rabbely crack that is usally a bit dirty- some loose blocks here and there. Belay spot very comfy!
content.protection: Can be led but crux pro is in loose rock, very unnerving. No fixed pro / anchors.   Can be TR'd with Dead Dogs.
content.location: Located on 2nd prominent wall between Arrowhead and the main face. Usually start from the ledge, by the tree. SNS follows through the depression straight to the top.

content.description: Start on Block Of Ages to get past the overhang, then step sideways and climb the face between them to the top of the pillar.Described as "Satanic Verses" in the old Nichols guidebooks and "Satanic Versus" in the Fasulo guidebook.
content.protection: standard ct trad rack, significant run-out on the second half.
content.location: The face between Arrowhead and Block Of Ages

climbs.name: Realm of the Senses
climbs.fa: FA: Chad Hussey, Mike Heintz, Tony Trocchi, 11/1981

content.description: Good face climbing past the two short overhangs.
content.protection: There are several trees at the top of the cliff that can make for a good anchor, but bring lots of webbing or static line because they're set back 20'+.

content.description: An ugly chimney to the left of Jaguar.
content.protection: I remember using a small nut near the top.

content.description: Negotiate the large, nasty looking overhang via a crack and climb to the top... Not a destination climb, for sure.
content.protection: Never seen it lead, usual CT TR anchor set up, static line, webbing, no fixed anchors.
content.location: Mid way through the crag, can't miss the crazy looking roof.

content.description: Pegasus is the obvious dihedral in the face of the crag.  A roof caps the dihedral near the summit.
content.protection: Small wires to a #2 Camalot.

climbs.name: Mind Bender Direct
climbs.fa: FA: possibly unknown, fixed pitons found in lower half  FA(finish on Golden Book): Casey Newman, Mike Heintz, 12/1975  FA(finish on Cat-o'Nine-Tails):

content.description: Climb the slab to a right facing corner, over steep blocks to the large block about 3/4 up. Work your way through the block to the roof, reach up and over and claw your way up for an exciting finish.
content.protection: Fixed gear missing, large cams to protect the roof.
content.location: Right facing corner / left of Golden Book.

content.description: Hard to ID the crux, the line doesn't flow real well, but worth a go.
content.protection: Top Rope anchoring off trees with obnoxiously long static line.
content.location: Face climb in the center of the wall between Arrowhead and main face. Close to neighboring Saturday Night, can be TR'd from the same anchor.

content.description: Jaguar climbs the face and arete just left of the Pegasus dihedral.  The crux is the last few delicate moves on the arete and establishing yourself on the face above the small roof. Straight up the arete here is slightly harder than using the holds on the face.  Harder variations can be done further left on the face.  Certainly the best route at Cathole and one of the best in CT.
content.protection: I have only toproped this; it would be very difficult to protect on lead.  Use long runners from trees on the clifftop.
content.location: Jaguar is pretty much the first route you see when you get to the crag.  The Pegasus dihedral is the most prominent feature on the right side of the cliff, the Jaguar arete forms the left wall of Pegasus.

content.description: One of the best face climbs around, sustained powerfull climb with not so great rests. Crux is getting to the overlap and pulling through. Great movement, figuring out the sequence is the fun of it all.
content.protection: TR set up is good with gear. No fixed anchors.
content.location: Blankish face to the left of Danzing, fingers are small and somewhat crimpy, fun project to test your limits. IW follows the line up the center of this face, to the left of the ice in the crack. The crux is at the right facing flake just under the small roof, pull through, step left and continue up the obvious line to the top, if you've got the juice.

climbs.name: Golden Book
climbs.fa: FA: Ken Nichols, Chris Stone, Dusty Nelson, 11/1975

content.description:
The big corner around the corner to the right from Pegasus - just after you duck under a block leaning against the face. 

  Can easily be led.
content.protection: Standard rack

content.description: Start just left of the three overlaps of Triple Direct, directly beneath a rectangular notch in the lower corner of the big roof.  Pull the roof at the notch and move left across the face to a crack for 8 feet.  Then diagonal right to a stance below the arête formed by the Phantasmagoria corner.  Finish up the right side of the arête.
content.protection: Trees at top suitable for TR anchors (with long static or webbing)
content.location: Toward the right side of the large Phantasmagoria roof, just left of the three overlaps of Triple Direct. Walk off left (or right).

content.description:
An intimidating, old-school 5.9 that deserves more traffic.  The moves are interesting and varied.  Excellent rock quality (for Cathole). 

  Climb up to the overhang and try to figure out the crux (next to the first overlap) before you pump out.  Catch your breath and follow the crack past the other two overlaps, then step left and continue straight up the finger crack and varnish to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2".  Trees at top suitable for TR but you need long static or webbing.
content.location: The obvious crack on the right side of the Phantasmagoria roof, just right of three distinct overlaps.  Walk off left (or right).

content.description: A little-known gem. Great moves on good rock with decent protection. Scramble up on the right of a large tree then climb the center of the narrow, right-facing wall following the small crack that runs up the middle.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Trees at top for TR anchors, but you need a long static and it's reportedly a bit tricky to get the master point above the line since the trees are off to the right.
content.location: On the right-facing wall between the Acid Reign arête and Chimney-Top Corner  below a large hemlock tree.  Walk-off left or right.

content.description: Follow the obvious open-book corner and crack.  Make sure to get a bomber piece in before the first ledge.  The crux is at the top.  Place pro thoughtfully to avoid dislodging potentially loose rocks in a fall.  There are usually a lot of loose stones right on the edge as you top out.
content.protection: Standard rack. Cams to 3".
content.location: To the right and uphill of the cave-like overhang start for Friday the 13th, Triple Direct, and Fool's Mate.  Walk off climbers trail left (or right).

content.description: Danzing follows the face almost straight up through the arking crack (seen with ice in it). Sustained climb with little to no rests, work up to the overlap and small roof, same finish as Imperial Wizard.
content.protection: Top roped- gear anchor is good or bring a mile of static line...
content.location: Route is on the prominent face that greets you from the access trail from the road on the south end of the crag.

content.description: hard start(crux) with solid cam to keep you off the ground. very pumpy start all the way to the ledge 25' up. second crux is up high, a little hard to protect especially if under 6'tall. good warmup for White Fandango.
content.protection: normal rack, maybe an extra .75 and #1 camalot would be nice too.
content.location: this route is 15' left of White Fandango and starts below a double crack that takes you to the ledge. from there go left up dihedral to  tree anchor.

content.description: Good beginer climb, little to no exposure, short easy and fun!
content.protection: Standard CT rack...   TR anchor with long static line.
content.location: Mid crag, look for the trees shown in photo.

content.description: Climb the right facing corner just to the left of Claw Marks. 5.7- Nice route with interesting moves. There is some loose stuff at the top. PG.
content.protection: Standard Trad Rack.

content.description: On the face to the right of the tall, freestanding flake.  Climb the thin face to a one foot wide overlap.  Pull over, move left, and follow the left-facing corner and crack above.
content.protection: Small pro and not much of it.  Particularly hard to protect the initial face. You can climb Catapult and Realm of the Senses from the same top rope set-up.

content.description: Climb the face and outside corner right of Pegasus.  Stay right of Pegasus, on the face all the way to the top.
content.protection: standard trad rack.

climbs.name: Call it "41a"
climbs.fa: Unknown  acb R Hall & S Matz 7/16/11

content.description:
Between Saturday Night Special (climb # 41 in Blue Book) and Catnip (climb # 42)  

  Start on the block 20ft right of SNS. Climb up on good holds, then left of flake (5.7) or on flake (5.6) to the top  5.6-5.7  R/X or TR
content.protection: Not much, TR recommended.

climbs.name: Block of Ages
climbs.fa: FA: Bob F. Poirier, Stew Sayah, 10/1973

content.description: OK route, didnt take too much gear but easy except for one spot.
content.protection: normal rack

climbs.name: Arrowhead
climbs.fa: FA(crack): Stew Sayah, Bob F. Poirier, Bob W. Poirier, Steve Zadrick, 9/1973

content.description: Jam up the crack,  past a shallow roof and out through the arrowhead. Follow the crack up to a ledge, and face climb the rest of the way.
content.protection: There are several trees at the top of the cliff that can make for a good anchor, but bring lots of webbing or static line because they're set back 20'+.

content.description: The Main Walls offer routes at all levels of difficulty. While there are some excellent leads, most routes are top roped.  There is no fixed hardware so bring a long dynamic rope/webbing to reach trees that are well back from the cliff edge.  Watch for sharp edges.  Cathole is notorious for loose rock so wear a helmet at all times.
